I.  THE ENSUING PROGRAM 
 
1.  The Government of Uzbekistan has requested policy-based loans totaling $200 million 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s ordinary capital resources to support demand and 
supply measures that will broaden and deepen the country’s financial system and ground it in a 
strong legal and regulatory framework.1 The proposed Financial Markets Development Program 
will facilitate an increase in the capacity and size of the financial markets (program outcome) and 
support the emergence of a well-functioning financial system that is able to sustain basic capital 
and investment needs as well as the country’s longer-term economic objectives (in line with the 
country’s Roadmap for Reforms, 2019–2021) (program impact).2  
 
2.  The attached transaction technical assistance (TRTA) will support the diagnostic studies, 
the policy dialogue with the government, and the preparation of the proposed program. The 
program and the TRTA will be included in the country operations business plan (2020–2022), 
scheduled for approval in the third quarter of 2019.  
   
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Opportunity. The Government of Uzbekistan has accelerated its transition toward a 
market economy with the adoption of the Strategy on Actions for Further Development of 
Uzbekistan (2017–2021) and the follow-on Roadmap of Reforms (2019–2021).3 Both documents 
recognize the central role played by banks and capital markets in fostering this transition. The 
Roadmap of Reforms, in particular, tasks the government with modernizing and developing 
financial market infrastructure and services to better meet the needs of the real economy.4 The 
introduction of market-based financial instruments will mobilize private sector financing to alleviate 
the infrastructure deficit, lower the costs of financing business development needs, and enhance 
access to finance. Commercially oriented lending and investment practices will boost capital 
allocation in the wake of the government’s continued privatization efforts (also prioritized by the 
road map) and help maintain high rates of economic growth as the state’s economic contribution 
is gradually reduced. 
 
4.  ADB’s Strategy 2030 gives priority to the development of the finance sector and capital 
markets to support the development of the private sector and enhance financial stability.5 Private 
sector investment is identified as a key driver of economic growth and a source of employment

Manila. Specifically, the proposed program will be aligned with the strategy’s operational priority to strengthen

2 
generation in the course of Uzbekistan’s economic transition, and is a strategic area for ADB 
support, as outlined in the draft country partnership strategy for Uzbekistan (2019–2023).6 
 
5.  Development problem. The economy is overly reliant on bank financing—total bank 
assets account for 52.6% of gross domestic product as of the end of 2018.7 The banking system 
is highly concentrated, i.e., 77.5% of total bank assets are owned by the seven largest state-
owned banks, of which the largest accounted for 26.3% of total assets.8 The banks also rely on 
funding sources that expose them to interest rate and liquidity risks (maturity transformation risks, 
largely from deposits of maturities up to 5 years) and government-directed lending programs at 
below-market rates—crowding out market funding (and pricing) and narrowing access to credit 
largely to state enterprises.9 Moreover, the funding structure of Uzbek banks has led them to 
adopt conservative lending practices, i.e., limiting the tenor of loans, and imposing high collateral 
requirements and interest rates, which further restricts access to credit.10  
 
6.  Domestic capital markets currently do not play a significant role in financial intermediation 
and resource mobilization in the Uzbek economy. The free float market capitalization of the 
Tashkent Stock Exchange accounted for about 0.5% of the country’s gross domestic product as 
of 31 March 2019,11 with daily trading liquidity of about $200,00012—reflecting both the small scale 
and low trading liquidity of the exchange. Bond market development is equally constrained. 
Issuances in the primary market are dominated by government bonds, whereas corporate bond 
issuances are limited and costly. The government bond market is characterized by short-dated 
and infrequent issuances, and does not fulfill its role as a benchmark pricing reference; this 
renders the pricing of securities difficult and corporate bonds less attractive to both issuers and 
investors.13 Only 0.33% of the total amount of corporate securities (i.e., shares and bonds) were 
issued as corporate bonds (totaling SUM198 billion or about $23.5 million) as of 1 March 2019.14 
Regulatory barriers also restrict the issuance of corporate bonds—e.g., a requirement that an 
issuer be a profitable joint stock company and a prohibition on issuing bonds in excess of a 
company’s capital. On the demand side, major institutional investors are state-owned or state-
controlled domestic banks. The participation of investors across the maturity spectrum is critical 
to support market development. 
 
7.  ADB  intervention.  ADB  proposes  to  provide  up  to  $200  million  to  support  the 
development of financial markets by introducing reform measures to diversify the predominantly 
bank-based system of financial intermediation. This will (i) expand the sources of credit and limit 
the systemic impacts of economic shocks, (ii) reduce financing costs by stimulating healthy

3 
competition with the banks, and (iii) boost the capital markets’ contribution to meeting the 
increasing financing  requirements  of a growing  economy. The  proposed  Financial  Markets 
Development Program is scheduled to be submitted for ADB Board consideration in the second 
quarter of 2020. It was requested by the Government of Uzbekistan as a policy-based lending 
modality to be disbursed over two subprograms. 
   
8.  The TA will help the government prepare the design of its reform program and develop 
the capacity to implement it.15 The reform program will serve to remove the binding constraints in 
the development of the capital markets, i.e., (i) an opaque legal and regulatory framework with 
overlapping and contradictory mandates, (ii) ad hoc government debt management practices and 
absence of a clear capital market development strategy for debt issuances, (iii) shallow and illiquid 
corporate bond and equity markets, and (iv) inefficient (and costly) market trading platforms. The 
TA will also explore related issues to determine measures that would boost the participation of 
institutional  investors  in  Uzbekistan’s  securities  markets,  and  lay  the  groundwork  for  the 
introduction of alternative financing instruments (such as derivatives) as the financial markets 
develop. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
9.  The objective of the TA is to identify policy measures to support the development of a 
robust financial market system in Uzbekistan that is well balanced, sustainable and resilient, and 
able to effectively intermediate savings to finance investments.  
 
10.  Output 1: Securities market’s legal and regulatory framework streamlined and 
consolidated. This output will define measures to strengthen the legal and regulatory framework 
that governs Uzbekistan’s capital markets by (i) assessing the existing laws and regulations and 
(ii) proposing amendments with a view to removing undue complexity, broadening market access, 
and strengthening the legal rights of creditors and shareholders. It will also focus on setting 
suitable supervisory policies; defining regulatory areas that need strengthening to achieve better 
trading platforms and stronger market supervision; and identifying measures to strengthen the 
regulatory  capacity,  oversight  procedures,  and  enforcement  powers  of  the  Capital  Market 
Development Agency (established in January 2019). Finally, it will further assess and recommend 
measures  to  align  the  financial  reporting,  auditing,  and  disclosure  requirements  for  listed 
companies  with  international  standards,  with  clear  directives  on  accuracy  and  a  periodic 
disclosure regime; and to establish a reliable surveillance and enforcement system. These 
findings will be presented and discussed with key stakeholders and will form the basis of policy 
actions to be implemented under the proposed program. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Long-term  national  capital  market  development  strategy  and 
implementation plan formulated and implemented. The second output will focus on measures 
that allow an extension of the government yield curve and thereby further enable corporate bond 
market development. It will analyze the impediments to and recommend a strategy for achieving 
a deep, liquid, and transparent debt market with a wide range of products. It will also focus on 
making the pricing of primary corporate bond issuances more competitive, e.g., by promoting the 
role of credit rating agencies and developing a national credit risk database and rating system. 
Finally,  it  will  assess  the  procedures  and  integration  of  existing  trading  systems,  and 
recommended measures to improve the (cost) efficiency of market trading operations as well as 
the regulatory, surveillance, and enforcement functions. On the demand side, the output will 
assess measures to strengthen contractual savings institutions and pension funds, and initiatives

to increase institutional investors’ demand for corporate securities and participation in capital 
markets. The findings of dedicated technical studies will be presented and discussed with key 
stakeholders and reflected in the formulation of a long-term national capital market development 
strategy and implementation plan in accordance with the priorities of Uzbekistan’s key public and 
private sector stakeholders. The strategy will form the basis of policy actions to develop the 
government and corporate bond markets under the proposed program. International and regional 
experience in developing resilient and liquid equity and bond markets will be considered while 
formulating the strategy.  
 
12.  The consulting team will organize and facilitate up to three strategic workshops with 
Uzbekistan’s key capital market stakeholders—Ministry of Finance, Capital Market Development 
Agency, the central bank, and market participants—to present and consult on the findings and 
recommendations, and arrive at a consensus on the formulation of the final long-term national 
capital market development strategy and policy actions to be implemented under the ADB 
program. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $525,000, of which $500,000 will be financed by the Technical 
Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1.  
 
14.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, inter-agency coordination, and other in-kind contributions. The government was 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer and implement the TA with the support of its Uzbekistan Resident 
Mission. The Public Management, Financial Sector and Trade Division of ADB’s Central and West 
Asia Department will select, supervise, and evaluate the consultants.

17.  ADB’s procurement of consulting services. ADB will engage a consulting firm to 
implement the TA. It is estimated that 15 person-months of international and 3 person-months of 
national  consultants’  services  will  be  required;  the  proposing  entities  may  present  some 
adjustments with justification. Given the highly specialized expertise needed, the consulting firm 
will be engaged through quality- and cost-based selection using a standard quality–cost ratio of 
90:10. ADB will select the consulting firm based on a simplified technical proposal. The team of 
consultants will have expertise in capital market development and facilitation across diverse 
technical facets (including institutional, legal, and regulatory infrastructure) as well as in the 
development of alternative financing platforms and instruments. ADB will engage the consultants 
following its Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project 
administration and/or staff instructions. The outline terms of references for the TA consultants are 
accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2.

18.  Reporting requirements. The consulting team will submit to ADB and the government 
(i) an inception report within 2 weeks of mobilization; (ii) quarterly, midterm, and annual progress 
reports, to be submitted within 1 month from the end of each reporting period; and (iii) a draft final 
report 1 month before the end of the engagement and a final report 2 weeks before the end of the 
engagement. All reports shall be prepared in English, and key reports will be submitted in both 
English and Uzbek or Russian languages, as advised.
